BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A lot of snow has fallen over a wide area. Not yet all starting zones have released the snow entirely.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and wind from southerly directions, wind slabs formed in the last few days in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the sometimes deep wind slabs can be released naturally in all aspects.
In particular in starting zones where no previous releases have taken place and at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions large and, in isolated cases, very large dry avalanches are to be expected. Avalanches can occur again, even in paths where avalanches have already been released.
It is inadvisable to engage in ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking outside marked and open pistes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
A lot of snow is lying in all altitude zones. Over a wide area over a wide area 60 to 80 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Saturday.
Over a wide area new snow is lying on a hard crust. The new snow remains in some cases prone to triggering.
As a consequence of snowfall and the southerly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed at the weekend.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The meteorological conditions will cause a gradual decrease in the avalanche danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A lot of new snow to low altitudes: Large and very large dry avalanches are possible in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and wind from southeasterly directions, large surface-area wind slabs formed in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the wind slabs can be released naturally in all aspects. In particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation large and, in many cases, very large dry avalanches are to be expected. This applies especially in case of releases originating from starting zones that still retain some snow.
Including in starting zones in which avalanches have already been released natural avalanches, capable of reaching a long way, must be expected.
It is inadvisable to engage in ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking outside marked and open pistes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 70 to 90 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Saturday. In all altitude zones a very large amount of snow is lying.
As a consequence of snowfall and the southeasterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed at the weekend. In isolated cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
Towards its surface, the snowpack is weak. The new snow of the last few days remains prone to triggering in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will not decrease for the time being.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From starting zones at higher altitudes large natural avalanches, capable of reaching the valleys, must be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong southeasterly wind, large wind slabs formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as above approximately 2200 m. Numerous large natural avalanches are possible, also in all aspects on steep slopes. In avalanche paths that are already filled with snow they can to an increasing extent reach the valleys.
The avalanches can occur again, even in paths where avalanches have already been released. In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation, avalanche activity has already peaked.
Dry avalanches can over a wide area be released, even by a single winter sport participant and reach large size in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
50 to 70 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1800 m. The new snow is poorly bonded with the old snowpack. Caution is to be exercised on wind-protected shady slopes. Towards its surface, the snowpack is unfavourably layered and its surface consists of surface hoar, this also applies on steep sunny slopes. Towards its surface, the snowpack is unfavourably layered and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will decrease gradually. The northwesterly wind will transport the new snow.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In all aspects more dry avalanches are possible, even large ones. In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation this applies especially.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and southeasterly wind, further wind slabs formed in the last few days.
In particular in starting zones where no previous releases have taken place and in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation large and, in isolated cases, very large dry avalanches are to be expected. They can occur naturally.
The older wind slabs are covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise. Above the tree line and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain the avalanche situation is dangerous.
It is inadvisable to engage in ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking outside marked and open pistes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 40 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Saturday. A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
As a consequence of snowfall and the southeasterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form.
In some places new snow is lying on a hard crust. The new snow will become increasingly prone to triggering.
Weak layers exist in the old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will not decrease for the time being.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As the precipitation becomes more intense the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of new snow and wind a high avalanche danger will prevail. The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the wind slabs that are forming over a wide area will become increasingly prone to triggering. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. In all aspects large to very large avalanches are possible. Gliding avalanches can also occur. Single snow sport participants can release avalanches very easily.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area intensive precipitation. As a consequence of new snow and wind from southerly directions, further wind slabs will form. In particular places where weaknesses exist in the old snowpack are especially precarious.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Restraint is advisable on this first sunny day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Large quantities of fresh snow and the wind-drifted snow can be released easily in all aspects above the tree line. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Caution is to be exercised in particular on steep shady slopes, as well as adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation numerous loose snow avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, in particular medium-sized ones.

Avalanches can also be triggered in the old snowpack. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Places where surface hoar has been covered with snow are especially unfavourable. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.
In addition small to medium-sized gliding avalanches and wet snow slides are possible, in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
30 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen. The wind was storm force in some cases. Fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes above the tree line. The new snow of the last few days is lying on surface hoar in particular on wind-protected shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to gradual moistening of the snowpack in particular on steep sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes.

Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the old snowpack in particular on west, north and east facing slopes. This applies above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh wind slabs remain prone to triggering in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. More gliding avalanches and wet snow slides are to be expected.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution. Gliding snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Caution is to be exercised on steep shady slopes, as well as adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls in particular at elevated altitudes. As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes strong wind from southerly directions, avalanche prone wind slabs formed.
Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack can be released by individual winter sport participants. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep shady slopes above the tree line. Places where surface hoar has been covered with snow are especially unfavourable. In particular in regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 4 (high) and in high Alpine regions the avalanche prone locations are more widespread and the danger is greater.
Avalanches can also be triggered in the old snowpack and reach large size. Great caution and restraint are required.
In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2400 m. These can reach quite a large size. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 25 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1500 m. As a consequence of the moderate to strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed. Fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers at elevated altitudes. They are very prone to triggering.
Faceted weak layers exist in the top section of the old snowpack on west, north and east facing slopes. This applies above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh wind slabs remain prone to triggering at elevated altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Restraint is advisable on this first sunny day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Large quantities of fresh snow and the wind-drifted snow can be released easily in all aspects above the tree line. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Caution is to be exercised in particular on steep shady slopes, as well as adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation numerous loose snow avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, in particular medium-sized ones.

Avalanches can also be triggered in the old snowpack. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Places where surface hoar has been covered with snow are especially unfavourable. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.
In addition small to medium-sized gliding avalanches and wet snow slides are possible, in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
30 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen. The wind was storm force in some cases. Fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes above the tree line. The new snow of the last few days is lying on surface hoar in particular on wind-protected shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to gradual moistening of the snowpack in particular on steep sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes.

Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the old snowpack in particular on west, north and east facing slopes. This applies above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh wind slabs remain prone to triggering in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. More gliding avalanches and wet snow slides are to be expected.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs in high Alpine regions. In particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. Gliding avalanches can be released at any time of day or night.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow and the large wind slabs represent the main danger. As a consequence of the snowfall slab avalanches are possible, even very large ones in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be unstable in particular on steep northeast, north and northwest facing slopes. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with the old snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong southeasterly wind, wind slabs formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as above approximately 2200 m. Fresh wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence. In particular at intermediate and high altitudes the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase.
Even single skiers can release avalanches easily. The current avalanche situation calls for experience and restraint.
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible, also in all aspects on steep slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1500 m. The new snow is poorly bonded with the old snowpack. Caution is to be exercised on wind-protected shady slopes. Towards its surface, the snowpack is unfavourably layered and its surface consists of surface hoar,, also on steep sunny slopes. Towards its surface, the snowpack is unfavourably layered and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will persist. The northwesterly wind will transport the new snow.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow can be released easily or naturally in all aspects above approximately 1500 m. The snowfall will give rise as the day progresses to rapid softening of the old snowpack over a wide area especially at intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the snowfall numerous medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large ground avalanches are possible above approximately 1500 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. In addition the new snow-covered wind slabs must be taken into account. The new snow and wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant,.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area intensive precipitation. As a consequence of new snow and wind from southerly directions, further wind slabs will form. In particular places where weaknesses exist in the old snowpack are especially precarious.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Above approximately 1200 m snow fell on Sunday over a wide area. In some localities 40 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2000 m. In particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation and on steep slopes medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of the new snow. The new snow and wind slabs can be released easily in all aspects above the tree line. Individual gliding avalanches can also occur. As a consequence of the rain, the likelihood of gliding avalanches and snow slides being released will increase on very steep slopes below approximately 1600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area new snow is lying on the soft surface of an old snowpack. The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on northwest to north to northeast facing aspects above approximately 2500 m. The fresh wind slabs are to be assessed with care and prudence. In particular slopes adjacent to ridgelines are especially precarious.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Restraint is advisable on this first sunny day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow and wind slabs can be released easily in all aspects above the tree line. Avalanches can reach medium size. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Caution is to be exercised in particular on steep shady slopes, as well as adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation numerous loose snow avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, but they will be mostly small.

Avalanches can also be triggered in the old snowpack. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Places where surface hoar has been covered with snow are especially unfavourable. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.
In addition small to medium-sized gliding avalanches and wet snow slides are possible, in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen. The wind was storm force in some cases. Fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes above the tree line. The new snow of the last few days is lying on surface hoar in particular on wind-protected shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to gradual moistening of the snowpack in particular on steep sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes.

Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the old snowpack in particular on west, north and east facing slopes. This applies above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh wind slabs remain prone to triggering in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. More gliding avalanches and wet snow slides are to be expected.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow is to be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The soft wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on steep shady slopes at high altitude. In many cases avalanches are medium-sized and can be released easily even by a single winter sport participant. On steep grassy slopes many moist snow slides are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation. In very isolated cases the gliding avalanches are large.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area over a wide area 30 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1500 m. As a consequence of the moderate to strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are in some cases prone to triggering. At low altitude hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh wind slabs remain prone to triggering at elevated altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong to storm force southerly wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed. The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above the tree line. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation loose snow avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, but they will be mostly small.

In addition a certain danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes. These can in isolated cases reach medium size. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind was strong to storm force in some cases. 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen. Fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh wind slabs remain prone to triggering at elevated altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong to storm force southerly wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed. The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above the tree line. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation loose snow avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, but they will be mostly small.

In addition a certain danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes. These can in isolated cases reach medium size. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind was strong to storm force in some cases. 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen. Fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh wind slabs remain prone to triggering at elevated altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be in most cases moist. Gliding avalanches can be released at any time of day or night.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Individual, then as the precipitation becomes heavier more, and in some cases even medium-sized, gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of mild temperatures and snowfall the snowpack can not consolidate.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust only at high altitudes and will soften during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As the moisture increases individual mostly small wet snow slides and avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The new snow is lying on the quite favourable surface of an old snowpack.
